metadata.title: Growth and Enzymatic Activity of Maize (Zea mays L

sections.text:
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
Copper (Cu) is an essential micronutrient for plants, which acts either as the metal component of enzymes or as a functional structural or a regulatory co-factor of a large number of enzymes. To understand the possible benefits of applying nanotechnology to agriculture, the first step should be to analyze penetration and transport of nano particles in plants. The present study was conducted to test the hypothesis that copper nanoparticle would enter into the plant cell and govern the growth of maize plant.A solution culture experiment was conducted to investigate the effect of Cu nano particles (<50nm) on the growth and enzymatic activity of maize (Zea mays L.)plant.Bioaccumulation of Cu nano particles in plant was also investigated.Results showed that Cu nano particles can enter into the plant cell through roots and leaves. increased with increasing concentration of Cu nano particles (NPs), and agglomeration of particles was observed in the cells using transmission –electron microscopy.Application of Cu nano particles through solution culture as well as spray enhanced the growth (51%)of maize plant in comparison to control.The different enzymatic activities like glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, succinate dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, catalase, andguaiacol peroxidase were studied to find a possible pathway through which NPs may affect the enzymatic activity of plant. Amongst the enzymes, the activity of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase was highly influenced by copper oxide (CuO)nano particles application by spray as well as in solution.Experimental results revealed that CuOnano particles affected the pentose phosphate pathway of maize plant.The obtained experimental results provided conclusive evidence to indicate that nano particle considered under this study could enter into the plant cell, easily be assimilated by plants and also enhanced its growth by regulating the different enzyme activities.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Commercial and scientific interest in using nano particles (NPs)as a source of plant nutrients or alternative source of costly fertilizer and also to enhance the soil fertility has been growing briskly in recent years. Although nanotechnology presents great potential to influence various sectors in the areas of energy, environment, health care, and consumer goods,application of nanotechnology in agriculture, even at its global level, is at its nascent stage. Nanoscience is leading to the development of a range of inexpensive nanotech applications for enhanced plant growth. In the past few years, the synthesis of copper (Cu)nanoparticles has attracted much attention because of its huge potential for replacing expensive nano silver inks utilized in conductive printing. Copper NPs are one of the most important engineered NPs. They exhibit optical and electrical properties and are being used intensively in electronics, ceramics, films, inks, metallics, and coatings (Yang et al., 2006).Copper oxide (CuO) NPs are one of the major and frequently used engineered oxide NPs with significant industrial applications like catalyst, superconducting materials, thermoelectric materials, sensing materials, glass, ceramics, etc. Thus significant industrial production and applications of CuO NPs may lead to environmental exposure. Copper (Cu) is an essential nutrient for the growth of plants and plays an important role in the photosynthetic reactions. Copper activates several enzymes and contributes in RNA synthesis and improves the performance of photosystems. There are a few reviews about the effects of nano particles on plants. Studies showed that the effects of nano-particles on plants can be beneficial (seedling growth and development) or non- beneficial (to prevent root growth) (Zhu et al. 2008). structures owing to their small size and high surface reactivity govern the growth of plants.Maize (Zea maysL.) holds a unique position in world agriculture as food, feed, and industrial crop. Maize is now widely cultivated in India, and a greater weight of maize is produced each year than any other grain.The importance of maize or corn lies in its wide variety of applications besides serving as human food and animal feed. It is a source for a large number of industrial products such as maize corn, corn starch, corn oil, baby corn, popcorn, dairy feed, poultry feed, for piggery, in agro-industries, and so on. The huge potential for exports has added to the demand for maize. In industry,nano-CuO has been extensively used for several decades. But its application in agricultural field is still not emphasized and practiced so as to increase the nutrient use efficiency. Before application in field, characterization of nano particles is essential to understand its behavior and reaction kinetics in soils and plants.It is unpredictable how different nano materials interact with plants. Such an interaction varies with type and time of exposure to nano materials and hence these points need to be considered. Oxidative stress arises from an imbalance in the generation and metabolisms of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS), with more of ROS such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) being producedthan that is metabolized. The oxidative enzymes are known to deplete the pool of ROS from accumulating to toxic levels, and thus play an important role in adaptation and survival of plant during stress. The cellular antioxidant enzymes are believed to protect the cell. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) catalyses the conversion of superoxide ion to H2O2, whereas catalase (CAT) scavenges H2O2 and peroxidase (PER) uses H2O2 for oxidation of various inorganic and organic substrates. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the key regulatory enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and, as such, controls the flow of carbon through this pathway. Specifically, the enzyme catalyzes the first D ow nl oa de d by [ U ni ve rs ity o f L et hb ri dg e] a t 0 7: 44 2 8 Se pt em be r 20 15

reaction in the pathway leading to the production of pentose phosphates and reducing power in the form of NADPH to meet cellular needs for reductive biosynthesis and maintenance of the cellular redox state.Against this backdrop, the present investigation was carried out to investigate the effects of nano-copper oxide particles on growth and enzymatic activities of maize plant.

sections.heading: Characterization of CuO Nano Particles
sections.text: CuO nano particles were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO, USA) and were stored according to the vendor's instructions and used as received, with a purity of 99.5%, particle size of <50 nm. The morphology of the CuO nano particles was examined using transmission electron microscopy (Figure 1).

sections.heading: Preparation of Particle Suspensions and Copper Ion Solution
sections.text:
The nano particles were suspended directly in double distilled water and dispersed by ultrasonic vibration (100 W, 40 kHz) for 30 min. Small magnetic bars were placed in the suspensions for stirring before use to avoid aggregation of the particles. Copper ion (Cu +2 ) solution was prepared by dissolving copper sulfate heptahydrate (CuSO4.7H2O) in double distilled water.

Maize (Zea mays L.) plant was taken as a test plant. The seeds were purchased from Monsanto Company (Creve Coeur, Missouri, USA). Damaged or empty seeds hulls were discarded. The average germination rates of both the plants were greater than 90% as shown by a preliminary study. Seeds were kept in a dry place in the dark under room temperature before use.

sections.heading: Solution Culture Experiment
sections.text:
Seeds of maize crop were germinated in moist rock mass for about 12 days after sterilization and water soaking. Uniform seedlings were selected and transplanted to 1500 mL pots containing 1500 mL of nutrient solution (Table 1) (Hoagland and Arnon, 1950).
In order to eliminate iron deficiency, 1 ml 0.5% Iron tartarate was added to the solution.
The final solution pH was 6.5.All of these chemicals were analytical grade with a purity of >98%. One seedling was planted in each pot through hole. The open areas between plastic and seedlings were sealed with sponge. Roots of the seedlings were submerged into the nutrient solution. The seedlings were allowed to grow in the nutrient solution for three weeks. The nutrient solutions were aerated continuously and the pH was adjusted to 6.0 (± 0.01) daily by addition of 1(N) sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and 1(N) hydrochloric acid (HCl) throughout the experiment. Plants were grown under controlled environment conditions with day/night temperature regime 25°C/18°C; 14h/10 h light- /dark (photoperiod); photo flux density at leaf level about 400 µ mol cm -2 . The experiments were carried out in a completely randomized design withfour replications. The supernatant was used to assay the activity of SOD. The enzyme activity was determined following the method described by Kunand Abood (1949).

sections.heading: Superoxide Dismutase
sections.text: SOD was estimated following the method of Dhindsaet al., (1981). Each 3 ml of the assay mixture consisted of 0.1 ml supernatant, 1.5 ml phosphate buffer (0.1 M, pH 7.8), 0.1 ml sodium carbonate (1.5 M), 0.1 ml nitroblueterazolium[NBT (2.25 mM)], 0.2 ml methionine (200 mM), 0.1 ml ethylenediamine tetra-aceticacid [EDTA (3 mM)], 0.1 ml riboflavin (60 μM), and 0.8 ml distilled water. Absorbance was recorded at 560 nm, and one unit of enzyme activity was taken as the quantity of enzyme.

sections.heading: Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase
sections.text: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase was assayed spectrophotometrically by monitoring the rate of NADPH formation at 340nm in the presence of Glucose-6-phosphate and NADP (Steinbach et al., 1982). The specific activity of the enzyme was expressed as unit per mg of protein.

sections.heading: Plant Sample Analysis
sections.text: To determine NP accumulation in plant tissue after 4 days, all plants were washed thoroughly with distilled water to remove the test medium. Plant samples analyses were done by dry ashing in muffle furnace and the ash was finally dissolved in 2N hydrochloric acid (Chapman and Pratt, 1982). Elemental analysis in digests was performed by ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA).

sections.heading: Effect of CuO Nano Particles on Growth of Maize Plant
sections.text:
Results of solution culture experiment revealed that the seedlings of maize, grown at different levels of copper recorded the growth rate differently. Where no copper (control) was added, seedling growth was retarded. It pointed out that the maize plant showed response to CuOnano particles. The maize seedlings at adequate level of nutrient solution stimulated the growth might be due to increase in concentration of essential nutrients in tissues and their participation without any hindrance in different metabolic functions such as reserve mobilization, solute translocation,

respiration, growth and photosynthesis (Marschner, 2002). The dry weight of both shoot and root of maize seedlings increased at different levels of Cu supply from that of without Cu application ( Figure 2, 3). The dry weight of shoot and root was increased due to application of Cu through CuSO4, and nano CuO (<50 nm). The seedling biomass was increased with the application of CuO nano particles and its spray. But the highest dry matter weight of shoot (5.12 g) and root (0.76 g) was recorded at 0.5 ppm Cu through CuO nano particles. The shoot Cu content was varied from 14 ppm to 37 ppm at control and 0.5 ppm Cu level where as in root highest Cu content was recorded at 0.5 ppm Cu through nano CuO particles. Increasing copper supply increased tissue copper in shoot and root (Figure 4, 5). A similar relationship between the supply and tissue concentration has been suggested earlier by several workers (Tanyolac et al., 2007). The concentration of copper was higher in the roots of plants than in the shoots. The copper uptake is a metabolically mediated process and the element is taken up either as a divalent cation (Cu +2 ) or as Cu chelate. The displacement of several ions from root exchange sites by copper has been reported because copper is very strongly bound in the root free spaces. These observations account for the frequently higher copper content in the roots than other plant tissues (Marschner, 2002).

The cross section of corn leaf, where CuO nano particle was not applied through spray or in solution, showed no deposition of CuO nano particles (Figures 6,7,8,9,10). Where CuO nano particle was applied through spray (8 ppm) on corn leaf, some electron-dense deposits were observed in the outer wall of the leaf epidermis and the particles possessed approximately the correct size range for the CuO nano particles (Figure 11). In the solution culture experiment, CuO nano particle was also applied at the level of 20 ppb and experimental results showed the deposition of CuO nano particles inside the root epidermal cells (Figure12). The penetration of CuO nano particles through the cell wall was prominent in Figure 13. The nano particles entered through the epidermal and cortical cells. After entering the cells, the nano particles transport from one cell to other through plasmadesmata. The Figures 14 and 15 demonstrated that particles seem to span the wall from outside to cytoplasm andfinally some particles were observed in the vacuole. It can be depicted from Figures 16 17,18 and 19 that there were no particles outside (upper left) there are dark materials at the cellwall - plasmalemma boundary and also in the vacuole of the cell to the right. The particles in the vacuole have the characteristics of the CuO particles.The dark particles were definitely the form/density of the CuO particles that were applied. The cross section of root cell (Figure 20) showed that deposition of cluster of CuO nano particle particles outside the surface of the epidermis. Particles firstly deposited on the wall (left, upper left) and then after crossing the wall reached cytoplasm and into the vacuole.The particles appeared less spherical than freshly prepared nano CuO suspension. sections.heading: Effect of Cuo Nano Particles on Enzymatic Activity of Maize Plant
sections.text:
The growth of plant was enhanced due to application of Cu through both the sources. This finding was also supported by enzymatic study. The different enzymatic activity like glucose-6phosphate dehydrogenase activity, succinate dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, catalase, guaiacolperoxidase was measured. It was observed that the activity of guaiacol peroxidase, catalase and superoxide dismutase was enhanced in control plants (Figure 21, 22, 23, and 24). It is attributed to arise of stress condition in plants due to Cu deficiency in solution culture. The enhanced activity of superoxide dismutase in all the plants in comparison to control was due to application of Cu in solution culture, as Cu is a cofactor of SOD. It could be depicted from Figure 25 that application of CuOnano particles through spray affected the pentose phosphate pathway. The first enzyme of the oxidative pentose phosphate pathway (Figure 26), glucose 6-P dehydrogenase was activated when CuO nano particle enters inside the cell.
Experimental data showed that this enzyme activity was more in case of CuOnano
particle spray on leaves (8.46 unitmg -1 of protein) in comparison to control plant (2.41 unitmg -1 of protein). Results indicated that plant leaves and roots might have the unique mechanism of assimilating nano-CuO particles and using for its growth and development.

The present study was conducted to know the effect of CuOnano particles on plant growth. As experimental results proved the beneficial effect of NP on plant growth, some logical explanation has been discussed in detail in favor of its penetration into plant cell and controls on enzymatic activity. Generally, higher plants strongly interact with their atmospheric and terrestrial environments and are expected to be affected as a result of their exposure to NPs. Roots and shoots are interdependent. The roots receive photosynthates and growth hormones from shoots and in turn furnish water and nutrients to shoots (Taylor and Arkin, 1981). After seed germination, plants generally contribute the major portion of the metabolites towards root expansion. For instance, radicle grows faster than the plumule of maize after germination. However, the trend is reverse at later stages of growth. The uptake efficiency and effects of various nano particles on the growth and metabolic functions vary differently amongst the plants. Besides application of Cu in solution culture media, foliar application was also practiced.Foliar adsorbed nutrients are immediately available to plants. Foliar nutrient absorption is not a biological process that requires time. It is very fast process because of it is governed by physical and chemical process. Chlorophyll production and photosynthesis rate were enhanced due to application of foliar fertilizer, which in turn increases the uptake of soil applied fertilizers in response to increased need for water by the leaf bringing more nutrients to the plant via the vascular system.However, accumulation of nano particles on photosynthetic surface cause foliar heating which results in alterations to gas exchange due to stomatal obstruction that produce changes in various physiological and cellularfunction of plants. Studies on the mechanism of nano particle uptake by plants still need more clarification. D ow nl oa de d by [ U ni ve rs ity o f L et hb ri dg e] a t 0 7: 44 2 8 Se pt em be r 20 15

sections.heading: Entry of CuO Nano Particles in Plant System
sections.text:
The present investigation was conducted to studythe mechanism how nano particles get entry into the plant cell. Nano particles can be applied to plants by different modes, in suspension through roots and in spray on leaves. Plant roots generally interact with nano particles present in the solution. Any external agent including nano particles cannot easily enter inside the plant cells. Plant cell wall acts as a barrier. The pore diameter, which generally varies from 5 to 50 nm, governs the sieving properties of the cell wall. Hence, only nano particles or nano particle aggregates with diameter less than the pore diameter of the cell wall could easily pass through and reach the plasma membrane. Another possible explanation of nano particles entry into plant cell is that due to their small size and huge kinetic energy, nano particles can penetrate the cell walls, which in turn enlarge the pore size. This phenomenon also helps to induce new cell wall
pores of larger size, whichfacilitates the uptake of nano particles of larger size ( 100 nm). The
ability of carbon nano materials to penetrate the cell wall and cell membrane of intact plant cells were also recently reported (Liu et al., 2009).The next step is internalization of nano particle inside the cell. This may occur during endocytosis with the help of a cavity like structure that from around the nano particles by plasma membrane. They may also cross the membrane using embedded transport carrier protein or through ion channels. In the cytoplasm, the nano particles may bind with different cytoplasmic organelles and interfere with metabolic processes at that site. Generally, several active and passive transport processes occurred across the root cells, which controlled the uptake and translocation of nano particles. The accumulation of nano D ow nl oa de d

Nano particles might enter the plant roots via osmotic pressure and capillary forces and enter through the cell wall pores and translocated through intercellular plasmadesmata. Since the aggregates were mostly found near the vascular systems, there is a possibility of hindrance to the uptake of water and nutrients, which is not good for the potential growth of plants. When nano particles are applied on leaf surfaces, they enter through the stomatal openings or through the bases of trichomes and then translocated to various tissues. Permeation of nano particles via cuticularnanopores was also possible. Ectodesmata are pores with a diameter of less than 1nm. These pores are readily permeable to solutes (<1nm). The mechanism of foliar absorption of nano particles is not well understood. Plants absorb nutrients as well as other chemicals/substances through their foliage to varying degrees. The leaf surface is composed of layers of cuticular wax, followed by the cuticle. The cuticle exudes the wax. Under the cuticle are the cell walls of various types of leaf cells. Inside the cell walls are the plasma membranes of the cells themselves.A foliar applied nutrient must pass through the cuticular wax, the cuticle, the cell wall, and then the membrane. Sometimes the nutrient will pass through these various layers, while other times it may pass through the spaces between these layers. Such absorption involves both active and passive processes of the leaf. Most often themajor means of foliar absorption is through the stomates, which are microscopic pores in the epidermis of the leaf. When the stomates are open, foliar absorption is often easier. Plant species vary widely in thenumber of stomates per leaf area, and in their relative distribution. Some plants have more stomates on the lower leaf surface than on the upper and some vice versa. More research should be focused on the generation of novel nano particles enlarging the pore size of plants’ cell wall upon their interaction with wall proteins and polysaccharides resulting in their successful transfer to plant system.

sections.heading: Enzyme Activity
sections.text:
As nano particles are alien particles to plant, after entering in to plant cell it is speculated that the nano particle may generate some oxidative stress in plant cells which in turn affected photosynthesis and led to decreased metabolic process rates. In order to investigate the stress in plants due to application of nano particle, different enzyme activity was studied. Experimental results showthat the activity of stress enzymes like succinate dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, catalase,and guaiacol peroxidasearenot induced by the application of different doses of CuOnano particles.Moreover, it was observed that glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity was induced due to application of the nano particles. It is speculated that the nano particles affect the oxidative pentose phosphate pathway and enhance the crop yield by increasing the photosynthetic rate. Based on the experimental evidence, scientistsmay know whether nano particles inside the plant might increase its yield.In order to understand the effect of nano particles on plant growth further detailed study has to be conducted.
The overall results depicted that the presence of CuO nano-particles improved the growth
of maize seedlings. Therefore, it may be hypothesized that nano-particles can penetrate the plant cell, which warrants further research. Moreover, two basic questions, namely, i) whether plants

Theobtained experimental results provided conclusive evidence to indicate that i) nano particle considered under this study could easily be assimilated by plantsii) enhanced growth of maize due to nano-CuO (<50 nm). It was also found that CuO nano-particles could enhance the plant growth by regulating the glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity.Nanoparticles spray provides an efficient means to distribute fertilizers in a controlled fashion with high site specificity thus reducing collateral damage. The interaction of plant cell with the nano particles results in modification of plant gene expression and associated biological pathways, which ultimately affect plant growth and development. Hence, future studies needto clarify the possible uptake and translocation of nanoparticles by plants, and physical and chemical properties of nanoparticles in the rhizosphere and on root surfaces.

metadata.abstractText: Copper (Cu) is an essential micronutrient for plants, which acts either as the metal component of enzymes or as a functional structural or a regulatory co-factor of a large number of enzymes. To understand the possible benefits of applying nanotechnology to agriculture, the first step should be to analyze penetration and transport of nano particles in plants. The present study was conducted to test the hypothesis that copper nanoparticle would enter into the plant cell and govern the growth of maize plant.A solution culture experiment was conducted to investigate the effect of Cu nano particles (<50nm) on the growth and enzymatic activity of maize (Zea mays L.)plant.Bioaccumulation of Cu nano particles in plant was also investigated.Results showed that Cu nano particles can enter into the plant cell through roots and leaves.
